content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Geneticists investigated the mode of inheritance of a rare disorder that alters glucose metabolism and first shows symptoms in adulthood. The geneticists studied a family in which some individuals of generations <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are known to have the disorder. Based on the pedigree (Figure 1), the geneticists concluded that the disorder arose in individual <math alttext="2 in generation 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and was caused by a mutation in mitochondrial <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 1. Pedigree of a family showing individuals with the glucose metabolism disorder. A question mark indicates that the phenotype is unknown. TABLE 1. AVERAGE BLOOD GLUCOSE LEVELS OF INDIVIDUALS IN GENERATION <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Individual Average Blood Glucose Level <math alttext="(in milligrams per deciliter, plus or minus, 2 S E sub x bar)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mo>(</mo><mrow><mtext>mg/dL</mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mo>±</mo><mspace></mspace><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>190</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="Individual 3 in generation 4" PHENOTYPIC CLASSIFICATIONS BASED ON BLOOD GLUCOSE LEVELS Phenotype Blood Glucose Level <math alttext="(in milligrams per deciliter)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mg/dL)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Normal <math alttext="less than 140 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo><</mo><mtext>140 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> At risk <math alttext="140 to 199 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>140 </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>199 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Affected <math alttext="greater than or equal to 200 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>≥</mo><mtext>200 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) The disorder alters glucose metabolism. Describe the atoms AND types of bonds in a glucose molecule.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Geneticists investigated the mode of inheritance of a rare disorder that alters glucose metabolism and first shows symptoms in adulthood. The geneticists studied a family in which some individuals of generations <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are known to have the disorder. Based on the pedigree (Figure 1), the geneticists concluded that the disorder arose in individual <math alttext="2 in generation 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and was caused by a mutation in mitochondrial <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 1. Pedigree of a family showing individuals with the glucose metabolism disorder. A question mark indicates that the phenotype is unknown. TABLE 1. PHENOTYPIC CLASSIFICATIONS BASED ON BLOOD GLUCOSE LEVELS Phenotype Blood Glucose Level <math alttext="(in milligrams per deciliter)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mg/dL)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Normal <math alttext="less than 140 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo><</mo><mtext>140 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> At risk <math alttext="140 to 199 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>140 </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>199 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Affected <math alttext="greater than or equal to 200 milligrams per deciliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>≥</mo><mtext>200 mg/dL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) The disorder alters glucose metabolism. Describe the atoms AND types of bonds in a glucose molecule.

(b) Using the template in the space provided for your response, construct an appropriately labeled graph based on the data in Table 1. Determine one individual who is both at risk of developing the disorder and has a significantly different blood glucose level from that of individual <math alttext="1 in generation 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Based on the pedigree, identify all individuals in generation <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> who can pass on the mutation to their children.

(d) Based on the fact that individual <math alttext="2 in generation 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is affected, a student claims that the disorder is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Based on the student’s claim, predict which individuals of generation <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be affected by the disorder. Based on the pedigree, justify why the data do NOT support the student’s claim.
